creditline: The Helen Jones Fund for Asian Art
description: high fired celadon glaze; banding of body and cover, thin bands of hatch marks divide wider bands of uniform curcular designs
medium: Stoneware with impressed and applique decor under a light yellow-green glaze
text: Three-legged ceremonial bronze vessels called ding were frequently copied in less expensive celadon glazed stoneware during the Warring States period. Intended for burial with the deceased, the vessel probably contained food intended for the afterlife. The stamped, spiral patterns of the lid, upright loop-handles, and legs are done in rather close approximation of contemporary bronze vessels. Lidded tripods similar to this one have been recovered from Warring State tombs at Chongxian, Zhejiang province, an important region in the early development of celadon.
title: Ding Tripod with Cover
